greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = least positive k such that (2n+1)+2^k is prime, or 0 if no such k exists.
comment: It is known that a(39278) = 0, since no such prime exists for the Sierpiński number 78557 (cf. A076336).
It has recently been discovered that 2131+2^4583176 and 41693+2^5146295 are probable primes, so a(1065) is probably 4583176 and a(20846) is probably 5146295.

At present, the only odd value less than 78557 for which no prime or strong probable prime of the form t+2^k is known is t = 40291, so a(20145) is completely unknown. In addition, for 25 values of t < 78557, only strong probable primes are known. (End)
The last case was resolved in 2011 when the probable prime 40291+2^9092392 was found as a part of a distributed project "Five or Bust". See links. - _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Mar 29 2019
link: T. D. Noe and Richard N. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..3000 (terms 0..1064 from T. D. Noe)
C. Rivera, Puzzle 167. Primes m + 2^j & m - 2^j, Prime Puzzles.
example: a(15)=4 because (2*15+1)+2^k is composite for k=1,2,3 and prime for k=4.
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(k=1); while (! isprime((2*n+1)+2^k), k++); k;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Feb 26 2018
results.author: _Don Reble_, Feb 05 2002
